key_insight: A neural stochastic differential equation (SDE) framework that learns state-dependent drift and diffusion can accurately generate and predict continuous-time cell state dynamics, outperforming prior methods and enabling in silico perturbation studies of development and disease.
problem_solved: Existing models struggle to capture the continuous, stochastic, and state-dependent nature of single-cell dynamics and to produce realistic perturbation simulations from snapshot or time-series single-cell data.
method: Parametrize drift and diffusion functions with neural networks to form a generative neural SDE that evolves cell states in continuous time.
Train the model on single-cell measurements (snapshots/time series) using likelihood-based / variational techniques while accounting for measurement noise.
Use the learned state-dependent noise and dynamics to simulate interventions and predict downstream effects (in silico perturbations).
impact: Provides ML practitioners a flexible, interpretable generative model for continuous-time stochastic systems, improving predictive accuracy for biological time series and enabling principled simulation of interventions transferable to other domains with noisy temporal data.
visual_elements: Schematic of a neural SDE: neural nets outputting drift and diffusion feeding into a stochastic integrator to produce cell trajectories.
Overlay of real vs. generated cell trajectories in state space showing improved fit versus baseline methods.
Before/after perturbation simulation in latent space illustrating predicted trajectory shifts under an intervention.
Bar or scatter chart comparing quantitative performance metrics (likelihood, forecasting error) across methods.
paper_title: Learning cell dynamics with neural differential equations
paper_authors: Michael E. Vinyard, Anders W. Rasmussen, Ruitong Li, Allon M. Klein, Gad Getz
